description: An organised campaign to eradicate the last remnants of the now extinct Charrúa people executed by the Uruguayan Army under the command of Uruguayan president Fructuoso Rivera.
location: Banks of the Salsipuedes Creek, Uruguay

perpetrators.leading_group: Bernabé Rivera, nephew to Fructuoso Rivera

attacks: El Paso del Sauce del Queguay
La_Campaña_de_Salsipuedes.legend: First attack was a betrayal where Charrúas were called to join forces but were attacked when off guard.

aftermath.prisoners_march: Prisoners were forced to walk 260 km to Montevideo, where they were sold as slaves.
aftermath.exhibited_in_Paris: Four of the prisoners were sold and taken to Paris in 1833 to be exhibited in a human zoo.
aftermath.memorial: A monumental sculpture, Los Últimos Charrúas, built in Montevideo in memory of the four Charrúas.

exclusions.Polish_Legionnaires: Given amnesty and Haitian citizenship for their support of Haitian independence.
exclusions.Germans: Not targeted and granted citizenship for not participating in the slave trade.

notable_victims.María_Micaëla_Guyunusa: Pregnant woman at the time of capture

cultural_impact: The massacre and its aftermath were part of the broader historical narrative of the erasure and genocide of indigenous populations in the Americas.

references.title: Pruebas irrefutables demuestran el genocidio de la población charrúa

references.author: Pablo Albarenga
references.title: Where did Uruguay's indigenous population go?

references.author: Wilfredo Alayón
references.title: Uruguay and the memory of the Charrúa tribe
